metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: R Data Set
Data Set
A data set is a collection of data, often presented in a table.
content.html: A data set is a collection of data, often presented in a table.

content.text: There is a popular built-in data set in R called " mtcars " (Motor Trend Car Road Tests), which is retrieved from the 1974 Motor Trend US Magazine.
content.html: There is a popular built-in data set in R called "mtcars" (Motor Trend Car Road Tests), which is retrieved from the 1974 Motor Trend US Magazine.

content.text: In the examples below (and for the next chapters), we will use the mtcars data set, for statistical purposes:
content.html: In the examples below (and for the next chapters), we will use the mtcars data set, for statistical purposes:

content.code_html:
# Print the mtcars data set
mtcars

content.text: Information About the Data Set
You can use the question mark ( ? ) to get information about the mtcars data set:
content.html: You can use the question mark (?) to get information about the mtcars data set:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
# Use the question mark to get information about 
  the data set?mtcars

# Use the question mark to get information about 
  the data set

content.code:
# Use the question mark to get information about
the data set?mtcars

syntax_highlighting.text:
# Use the question mark to get information about 
  the data set?mtcars

# Use the question mark to get information about 
  the data set

content.code_html:
# Use the question mark to get information about the data set

?mtcars

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
# Use the question mark to get information about 
  the data set?mtcars

# Use the question mark to get information about 
  the data set

content.text: Get Information
Use the dim() function to find the dimensions of the data set, and the names() function to view the names of the variables:
content.html: Use the dim() function to find the dimensions of the data set, and the names() function to view the names of the variables:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Cars <- mtcars # create a variable of the mtcars data set for better 
  organization# Use dim() to find the dimension of the data set
  dim(Data_Cars)# Use names() to find the names of the variables from 
  the data setnames(Data_Cars)

# create a variable of the mtcars data set for better 
  organization
# Use dim() to find the dimension of the data set

# Use names() to find the names of the variables from 
  the data set

content.code:
Data_Cars <- mtcars # create a variable of the mtcars data set for better
organization# Use dim() to find the dimension of the data set
dim(Data_Cars)# Use names() to find the names of the variables from
the data setnames(Data_Cars)

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Cars <- mtcars # create a variable of the mtcars data set for better 
  organization# Use dim() to find the dimension of the data set
  dim(Data_Cars)# Use names() to find the names of the variables from 
  the data setnames(Data_Cars)

# create a variable of the mtcars data set for better 
  organization
# Use dim() to find the dimension of the data set

# Use names() to find the names of the variables from 
  the data set

content.code_html:
Data_Cars <- mtcars # create a variable of the mtcars data set for better organization

# Use dim() to find the dimension of the data set
 dim(Data_Cars)

# Use names() to find the names of the variables from the data set
names(Data_Cars)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Cars <- mtcars # create a variable of the mtcars data set for better 
  organization# Use dim() to find the dimension of the data set
  dim(Data_Cars)# Use names() to find the names of the variables from 
  the data setnames(Data_Cars)

# create a variable of the mtcars data set for better 
  organization
# Use dim() to find the dimension of the data set

# Use names() to find the names of the variables from 
  the data set

content.text: Use the rownames() function to get the name of each row in the first column, which is the name of each car:
content.html: Use the rownames() function to get the name of each row in the first column, which is the name of each car:

content.code_html:
Data_Cars <- mtcars

rownames(Data_Cars)

content.text: From the examples above, we have found out that the data set has 32 observations (Mazda RX4, Mazda RX4 Wag, Datsun 710, etc) and 11 variables (mpg, cyl, disp, etc).
content.html: From the examples above, we have found out that the data set has 32 observations (Mazda RX4, Mazda RX4 Wag, Datsun 710, etc) and 11 variables (mpg, cyl, disp, etc).

content.text: A variable is defined as something that can be measured or counted.
content.html: A variable is defined as something that can be measured or counted.

content.text: Here is a brief explanation of the variables from the mtcars data set:
content.html: Here is a brief explanation of the variables from the mtcars data set:

content.text: Print Variable Values
If you want to print all values that belong to a variable, access the data frame by using the $ sign, and the name of the variable (for example cyl (cylinders)):
content.html: If you want to print all values that belong to a variable, access the data frame by using the $ sign, and the name of the variable (for example cyl (cylinders)):

content.code_html:
Data_Cars <- mtcars

Data_Cars$cyl

content.text: Sort Variable Values
To sort the values, use the sort() function:
content.html: To sort the values, use the sort() function:

content.code_html:
Data_Cars <- mtcars

sort(Data_Cars$cyl)

content.text: From the examples above, we see that most cars have 4 and 8 cylinders.
content.html: From the examples above, we see that most cars have 4 and 8 cylinders.

content.text: Analyzing the Data
Now that we have some information about the data set, we can start to analyze it with some statistical numbers.
content.html: Now that we have some information about the data set, we can start to analyze it with some statistical numbers.

content.text: For example, we can use the summary() function to get a statistical summary of the data:
content.html: For example, we can use the summary() function to get a statistical summary of the data:

content.code_html:
Data_Cars <- mtcars

summary(Data_Cars)

content.text: Do not worry if you do not understand the output numbers. You will master them shortly.
content.html: Do not worry if you do not understand the output numbers. You will master them shortly.

content.text: The summary() function returns six statistical numbers for each variable:
content.html: The summary() function returns six statistical numbers for each variable:

content.text: We will cover all of them, along with other statistical numbers in the next chapters.
content.html: We will cover all of them, along with other statistical numbers in the next chapters.
